results.title: The Real Story of Captain Cook's Death
results.brief_description:
Captain Cook encounters new territory and claims it. He is attacked by a native of the island and so flees. The native gets subsequently eaten by a big fish.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: The Mysteries of Ludwig Leicheart
results.brief_description:
This short film depicts the historical journey across the Top End made by Ludwig Leicheart and his horse Rusty. They eat and sleep and upon waking, Leicheart gets attacked and killed by a dingo. Leicheart’s trusty horse avenges his master’s death by killing the dingo.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.

results.title: Maidenhead
results.brief_description: Maidenhead is a series of chamber-fictions inhabited by a young woman named Alice. Linked in an oblique, dream like way, these short, sharp stories describe Alice’s survival in an everyday world of bizarre logic and strange emotions. It’s a place where miracles unfold in the bathroom and desire appears on a bus; where menacing joggers roam the suburbs and there’s something sinister about hats. Vibrant like musical, Maidenhead is at once funny and disquieting, poignant and absurd.

results.title: Random cuts
results.brief_description: At first glance, ‘Random cuts’ is a violent, rapidly shifting assemblage of images of violence, flight and impact from manga cinema, samurai films and a brutal cock-fight. On closer inspection, the apparent randomness of the images is revealed to be constrained by a mathematical formula. 12 images, each 1.6 seconds in length add and divide, repeating 12 times, increasing by the duration of the accumulating time units. The forceful incisions of the images and cuts find a taut restraint within this order, each element unresolved amid the visual violence.

results.title: The Way things go
results.creator_credit: Mirjam Krakenberger, Rainer Trinkler, Peter Fischli and David Weiss
results.brief_description: Inside a warehouse, artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss build an enormous, precarious structure 100 feet long made out of common household items - tea kettles, tires, old shoes, balloons, wooden ramps, etc. Then, with fire, water, gravity, and chemistry, they create a spectacular chain reaction, a self destructing performance of physical interactions, chemical reactions, and precisely-crafted chaos worthy of Rube Goldberg or Alfred Hitchcock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mirjam Krakenberger, Rainer Trinkler, Peter Fischli and David Weiss

results.title: Internal tantrum
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: In Internal Tantrum, Palestine sits before the camera with a severe expression of concentration, his body tense and his fists tightly wound. He begins to slowly chant and sway, evoking a powerful sense of grief and pain. He writes that the tape provides ‘a reading, like on the Richter Scale, of a certain kind of emotional internal roller coaster or earthquake. I used only one tone so the deliverance of energy becomes directly articulated in the sound.’ This performance is a simple yet intense rendering of pain, and the desire to move that pain outward from the internal.

results.title: Media Ecology ads
results.brief_description:
Muntadas, since the 1970s, has been preoccupied with the translation of information. In this series of three short films; Fuse, Timer and Slow Down, the artist focuses on the immediacy of the subjects
chosen for each film (a burning fuse, an hourglass, a running tap). An exploration of temporality and semiotics.
